DIV0.HEADING: Biography
DIV0.RESEARCHNOTE: kdc; Keller has another book, from 1999, called Pauline Johnson: first aboriginal voice of Canada. Could add to this from that.

SHORTPROSE.P:
PJ adopted her Mohawk name from her great-grandfather, and it means double wampum or double life.7 She explained that her surname was a baptismal name first taken by that great-grandfather, Jacob Johnson, whose real name was Tekahionwake. The T is pronounced as D, and K as a hard G.
One of PJ's biographies wrongly gives the meaning as smoke from many campfires.742

SCHOLARNOTE.P: PJ's pseudonym adopts the surname of her great-grandmother, Catherine Rollston, and was used for prose writing.8116221

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: PJ was born at the family home, Chiefswood, on the Six Nations Reserve near Brantford, Ontario.

P.BIRTHPOSITION: She was the youngest child and the second daughter.

SHORTPROSE.P: PJ grew up with servants, usually three: a nurse, a cook, and a man to oversee the stables. Her home had the accoutrements of a middle-class life including a piano, silver tea service, books . . . .49 Chiefswood was visited by nobility on two occasions. Biographers Carole Gerson and Veronica Strong-Boag describe the Six Nations Reserve at that time as a centre of Native resistance and an extraordinary community.32, 49 The Iroquois people of the reserve were noted for being vigorously intellectual and respectful of matrilineal traditions.33, 5023, 28
As the daughter of an English mother and a Mohawk father, PJ was attentive to issues of her dual heritage; by Canadian law she was deemed Indian. She identified herself as Mohawk.5

SCHOLARNOTE.P: There is no discrepancy in simultaneously identifying as Mohawk and Iroquois. The Iroquois Confederacy is an umbrella term for five First Nations: the Cayuga, Mohawk, Oneida, Onondaga, and Seneca. (The Tuscarora joined later to form the Six Nations.) Among the Six Nations, the Mohawk were regarded as risk-takers and innovators.33 The Confederacy was founded in the seventeenth century by Hiawatha (immortalized for readers of English in a popular poem by Longfellow, 1855, which was in turn parodied by Mary Cowden Clarke in 1856).33

SHORTPROSE.P: In her stage performances, PJ appeared in a buckskin dress of her own design and manufacture for the first half of the show, and then after a brief intermission, reappeared in a ball-gown (the costume of a white Victorian woman) for the second half. Critic Mary Elizabeth Leighton argues that she was enacting assimilation: the Native disappearing into civilized late-Victorian culture. The aboriginal outfit was, in a way, inauthentic: PJ collected artefacts from several different First Nations, so it did not truly represent Mohawk dress, for example. Among the accoutrements for this outfit was a necklace made from the claws of a bear which may have been a present from author and friend Ernest Thompson Seton. PJ did affirm that Seton gave her a bracelet of elks' teeth and mountain lion claws.148-9110162, 272 She had a wampum belt and bracelets made of white and purple shells, her father's knife at her belt, and a scarlet blanket. Her buckskin dress was adorned with silver brooches, fringes, ermine tails, rabbit pelts, her grandfather's Huron scalp, and another scalp bought in the United States. PJ knew that audiences came, in part, to see an Indian, and sometimes found herself described in promotional material or in reviews as The Mohawk Princess or Indian Poetess.148, 151258-943-4

Although she identified as Mohawk, PJ was also keen to identify herself as Canadian, provocatively stating in one poem (Canadian Born) that only those born in Canada could claim this identity. Despite this, US literary critics have sometimes adopted her as one of their own. On the back of one review that had mistaken her place of residence, she wrote, God forgive the slanderers. Why, oh why am I called a Bostonian?102

PJ's grandfather, John Smoke Johnson (or Sakayengwaraton, which means the haze that rises from the ground on an autumn morning and vanishes as the day advances,10 anglicised and shortened to Smoke), fought in the War of 1812 with the great Mohawk leader Joseph Brant; he was regarded as a hero and a renowned orator in Iroquois councils.91694

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: PJ's revered grandfather died, two weeks after making a public address recalling his old commander Joseph Brant.

SHORTPROSE.P: Her parents' wedding in 1853 attracted attention because an English woman was marrying a Mohawk man. A minister who was the brother-in-law of the bride refused to marry the couple and the wedding was held outside of Brantford in a futile attempt to keep away the curious. To calm some of the outraged Howells relatives, PJ's father wore an outfit appropriate for a stylish British man: black silk hat and satin waistcoat. PJ's Mohawk grandmother was also opposed to the marriage because she did not want a non-Native person entering the prestigious Johnson clan and because any children produced by the union would not be, under traditional law, Mohawk.15, 47
This was not, however, the first such marriage in the family. PJ also had a great-great-grandmother, a Dutch-American captive taken in by the tribe, who had married a Mohawk man.31, 46

SCHOLARNOTE.P: Critics Gerson and Strong-Boag name this great-grandmother Catherine Rollston Martin but then later give her middle name as Rollstone.46, 116

SHORTPROSE.P: PJ's mother, Emily Susanna Howells, was a Quaker born in Bristol, England. She had come to Canada from Ohio to visit a sister and to escape an over-strict father. She was a cousin to American author William Dean Howells. When she died in the winter of 1898, a great number of people attended her funeral, and Toronto papers balanced the scandal of her wedding against the long-lasting happiness of the union.11, 1374294

PJ's father was George Henry Martin Johnson, Onwanonsyshon, a Mohawk chief. He was at one time an interpreter for the Anglican church. He had a life-long interest in Napoleon and decided to name his children after Napoleon's circle of friends and family. (Pauline was named after Napoleon's sister, for example.) In one family photo, George wears the outfit appropriate to a Mohawk chief while affecting a Napoleonic pose.11, 14, 1946

George Johnson was present at the first telephone calls from the home of Alexander Graham Bell in Brantford, Ontario. When offered a chance to try the telephone, he deliberately confused the listener at the other end by speaking Mohawk.

George Johnson was severely beaten twice and shot once while trying to stop illegal activities on the Reserve. He was beaten with a lead ball on 21 January 1865 (sustaining a broken jaw and concussion) while trying to stop timber buyers from trading whisky with natives for timber, and again in October 1873 when trying to halt the sale of liquor. On both occasions his attackers were white men.29, 3195 On 24 April 1878 he was attacked by a native man and beaten a third time.39 He died partly from the long-term results of these attacks.31

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: PJ's father, George Johnson, died; his funeral procession was attended by community leaders from on and off the reserve.

SHORTPROSE.P: PJ's siblings were Henry Beverly, born in 1854, Eliza Helen Charlotte (known as Evelyn or Eva), born in 1856, and Allen Wawanosh, born in 1858.15-16, 50

Although PJ was not very close to her brothers, she and sister Eva had a closer but difficult relationship, damaged primarily by Eva's resentment, which began young. She was angered by the attention that her parents gave to Pauline as a sickly infant and later felt herself so unattractive as compared to Pauline that she cut her own face out of family photos. She was also angered by Pauline's inability to manage money.98-9
Eva was a key figure in the Brant Historical Society and wrote for the Ontario Historical Society's journal.100

PJ was educated at home first by her mother, who introduced her to the English Romantics. She was also taught by a governess in her early years. Chiefswood was full of books, and she read Milton, Shakespeare, Byron, Tennyson, Longfellow, and Scott.9443 PJ once claimed that she had read every line that Scott and Longfellow had written by the time she was twelve.30

Also important in her early education were the oral histories she heard from grandfather Smoke Johnson; he regaled her with war stories and Native legends. On the Grand River, she learned outdoor skills such as canoeing and camping.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: After attending a reservation school for three years, PJ left home to attend the Brantford Collegiate Institute.
After the death of her father, PJ, her mother, and her sister rented out Chiefswood and moved into the city of Brantford, Ontario.

SHORTPROSE.P: They lived at 7 Napoleon Street (now 7 Dufferin Avenue). The Brantford home passed out of the family when PJ's mother died in 1898.16

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: PJ was introduced in Hamilton, Ontario, to actress Mademoiselle Rhea, who persuaded her to get involved with the Hamilton Dramatic Society.

SHORTPROSE.P: PJ's literary career, which was highly performative, was likely launched by a reading in Toronto in early 1892 of A Cry from an Indian Wife.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: PJ toured Ontario, reciting poetry in fifty different locations.

SHORTPROSE.P: For some of these performances, PJ was matched with Englishman Owen Alexander Smily, an elocutionist, ventriloquist, and impersonator. Biographer Betty Keller likens the relationship to a marriage simply because they were together so much and travelling in isolation from their home communities. From him PJ garnered some of the techniques of elocution. Their partnership ended in 1897.66-8, 123
PJ covered many miles in the next years of performing. She crisscrossed Canada and the United States, often appearing on the same bill as a musician or a stand-up comedian.9545
She became one of the best known performers of her day, and her stagecraft remained her main source of income throughout her life.9545

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: PJ made her first trip to London, England, where she visited publishing houses and salons.

SHORTPROSE.P: In London, PJ visited and recited poetry before Edward Burne-Jones, George Frederic Watts, Frederic Leighton, Lawrence Alma-Tadema, and Jerome K. Jerome, among others.80

During her Canadian tours PJ met Canadian writers and poets. Ernest Thompson Seton affectionately called her my well-beloved cousin142 in correspondence, and Charles Mair, a sixty-year-old when he met PJ, responded quickly to her request for bears' teeth and claws from his home in northern British Columbia.162-3

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: During a tour of Manitoba, PJ met Canadian suffragist Nellie McClung, and they became close friends.

SHORTPROSE.P: In response to the support McClung had provided PJ while she was ill, she mentioned their friendship in her will.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Extensive touring took a toll on PJ's health; she was struck with severe erysipelasa type of streptococcal infection she had endured beforeand lost all of her hair.
PJ and her partner Walter McRaye visited the Copper Cliff, Ontario, home of noted journalist Kit Coleman.

SHORTPROSE.P: Kit Coleman was the first president of the Canadian Women's Press Club, of whose Vancouver branch later PJ was later a member.65
Much later, in 1913, PJ met Canadian poet Isabel Ecclestone MacKay, who interviewed her for the Canadian Magazine.195n35

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: PJ fulfilled a long-standing wish by travelling 400 miles up the Cariboo Road to Barkerville, British Columbia, where she first performed for an appreciative audience of over two hundred.

SHORTPROSE.P: The second evening, her audience numbered seventy-five.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: PJ became engaged to Charles Drayton, whom she had met in Winnipeg.

SHORTPROSE.P: The drama critic for the Globe and Mail announced the engagement and the proposed September wedding date in the 26 January issue, alongside a report of PJ's declining health.131-2

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: PJ's engagement to Charles Drayton ended when his family opposed his union with a woman who was older, not entirely white, and a stage performer.

SHORTPROSE.P: After the end of this relationship she may or may not have become romantically involved with her manager, Charles Wuerz, during 1900 and early 1901.6895157-8

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: After the death of her mother, PJ relocated to Winnipeg, Manitoba.

SHORTPROSE.P: PJ and her partner Walter McRaye returned to England in April 1906, staying at 53 St James's Square, London. On this trip she was introduced to Arthur Pearson, who invited her to write for his newspapers, which included the Daily Express.207-8, 216

During this visit she was invited to the home of Theodore Watts-Dunton, where she met Algernon Swinburne. When Charles G. D. Roberts met Swinburne two years later, the latter confirmed that PJ and her poetry had made a strong and favourable impression on him.218-19

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Chief Joe Capilano (Su--pu-luck) of the Squamish nation arrived in London, England, where he met PJ; after this meeting they formed a lasting friendship.

SHORTPROSE.P: Chief Joe was in London with two colleagues petitioning the British crown on behalf of British Columbia's First Nations.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: After returning briefly to Canada, PJ sailed back to London, staying again at 53 St James's Square.

SHORTPROSE.P: By early summer, however, she was back in Canada.

PJ and Walter McRaye undertook one of their last tours, beginning in July 1907, travelling through Indiana, Michigan, Iowa, Nebraska, Colorado, Kansas, Missouri, and Illinois, as part of a Chautauqua series.231-3
Chautauqua was the name given to groups of educators and entertainers who toured with tents through the American midwest and southern parts of Canada in the late 1800s and early 1900s, bringing their talents primarily to rural areas. The Chautauqua mission was related to that of the lyceum movement with its emphasis on self improvement.
On a tour of the west, PJ stopped in Edmonton, Alberta, to visit Ernest Thompson Seton on 4 November 1907.236

On 29 June 1908 PJ hinted to a reporter that her rest stop in Vancouver might be extended. She left the city in August, but soon retired from touring and settled in Vancouver, which became her final home.95238-9

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: PJ announced to a crowd in Vancouver's Pender Auditorium that she intended to settle in their city.

SHORTPROSE.P: Financial concerns were always a factor in PJ's living arrangements. She once claimed, Do you know what I would do if I had only two dollars in the world and I knew it would be my last? I'd spend half on my body and half on my soul. With one dollar I would buy a whacking good meal, and with the other a dozen cut carnations.99
In Vancouver, she lived in a small apartment and paddled around the bays of the city. She resumed her friendship with Chief Joe Capilano, whom she had met in 1906.17, 65

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Chief Joe Capilano began telling PJ the legends of the Squamish people.
PJ's friend Chief Joe Capilano died in Vancouver, British Columbia, on her birthday.

SHORTPROSE.P: In 1910 PJ was introduced to Isabel McLean, a journalist who published under the name Alexandra in the Vancouver Province. Through her, PJ became more involved with the Canadian Women's Press Club, though she was already familiar with the group because of her association with Kit Coleman.252

A friend persuaded PJ to see a doctor about the lump in her right breast. PJ found a young doctor, Thomas Ransom Biggar Nelles, who was not only highly qualified but had moved to Vancouver from Brantford. He had the unhappy job of telling PJ that her cancer was beyond remedy: all the help he could give her would be to manage pain.246-8

During her final days, PJ had a chance meeting on the streets of Vancouver with the novelist Ethel Wilson, who recognized her from having seen her at the age of eleven, when Johnson was giving a recital. Among the last visitors to her hospital bed was poet Charles Mair.259, 264

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: PJ died of breast cancer in Vancouver, British Columbia. She was three days short of her fifty-second birthday.

SCHOLARNOTE.P: Gerson and Strong-Boag in Paddling Her Own Canoe cite the date of death as 8 March 1913, but this goes against all other sources.

SHORTPROSE.P: Despite their troubled relationship, PJ's sister Eva was at her bedside, as was her former performing partner Walter McRaye.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: A memorial service for PJ was held at the Mohawk Chapel on the Six Nations Reserve near Brantford, Ontario.

SHORTPROSE.P: On the day of her funeral in Vancouver, flags in the city flew at half-mast, and her civic memorial on March 10, arranged to a great extent by the Women's Canadian Club, was attended by leading figures from Vancouver.17, 66

PJ is the only person buried in Stanley Park, Vancouver. Although she had requested an unmarked grave, the site is marked by a stone, erected by the Women's Canadian Club in 1922, on which is carved her profile, the prow of a canoe, a feather, a flint-tipped arrow, and the word PAULINE. Another memorial stone for her is located at the Mohawk Chapel in Six Nations Reserve near Brantford, Ontario.4517

WORKSCITED.SOURCE: Unless otherwise noted, all information is from the FC
New, W.H. (ed.) DLB Canadian Writers 1890-1920. vol. 92. Detroit: Gale Research Inc., 1990.
Keller, Betty. Pauline: A Biography of Pauline Johnson. Vancouver: Douglas and McIntyre, 1981
Gerson and Strong-Boag, Paddling her Own Canoe: The Times and Texts of E. Pauline Johnson. Toronto: UTP, 2000
Ruoff, Lavonne Brown, Native Women Authors in Karen Kilcup, ed.
